member.summary: Returns the specified collection, minus the given subset.
member.typeparam: The type of object in the collection.
member.param: The source collection.
The subset to remove from the source collection.
member.returns: Returns the source collection, minus the subset. If the subset was not found, then the source collection is returned without modification.

member.typeparam: The type4 of object in the collection.
member.param: The source collection.
The subset to remove from the source collection.
member.returns: Returns the subet collection if found in the source collection. If the subset was not found, then an empty collection is returned.

The collection to compare to.
member.returns: Returns true if both sequences contain the same values. Returns false if is null, or the sequences do not contain the same values.

member.summary: The base implementation of . This class can only be inherited.

member.summary: The parent call-chain.

member.summary: The associated children in relation to .

member.summary: A description of what this grouping represents or does within the scope of the application.

member.name: M:Capoala.CmdLine.CommandLineGroupingBase.#ctor(Capoala.CmdLine.ICommandLineArgument,Capoala.CmdLine.ICommandLineArgument[],System.String)
member.summary:
Creates new instance of .
*See remarks for further details and correct implementation.
member.param: The parent call-chain.
The associated children in relation to .
A description of what this grouping represents or does within the scope of the application.
member.exception: Throws when is null or contains not elements.
member.remarks:
The property represents the full parent hierarchy chain.
The property represents associated child pairings. It is important to note this property is not an "all inclusive" listing", but rather an individual grouping. This means that if you have one "main argument", which has three "child arguments", then specifying a grouping with "main" and "childOne" would transpose to the command line as "$ main childOne".
If you wanted to specify a grouping that states "main" must run with "childOne" and "childTwo", but leave "childThree" as optional, then you would create two groupings; one with "childOne" and "childTwo"; the other, with "childOne", "childTwo", and "childThree".

member.name: M:Capoala.CmdLine.CommandLineGroupingBase.#ctor(Capoala.CmdLine.ICommandLineArgument[],Capoala.CmdLine.ICommandLineArgument[],System.String)
member.summary:

*See remarks for further details and correct implementation.
member.param: The parent call-chain.
The associated children in relation to .
A description of what this grouping represents or does within the scope of the application.
member.exception: Throws when is null or contains not elements.
member.remarks:
The property represents the full parent hierarchy chain.
The property represents associated child pairings. It is important to note this property is not an "all inclusive" listing", but rather an individual grouping. This means that if you have one "main argument", which has three "child arguments", then specifying a grouping with "main" and "childOne" would transpose to the command line as "$ main childOne".
If you wanted to specify a grouping that states "main" must run with "childOne" and "childTwo", but leave "childThree" as optional, then you would create two groupings; one with "childOne" and "childTwo"; the other, with "childOne", "childTwo", and "childThree".
